_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Deer Park Refinery Risk Management Program Executive Summary



The location has a long-standing commitment to our workers, public safety, and the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the amount of resources invested in accident prevention, such as training of personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. The following executive summary provides a brief description of the location risk management program.



(a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source;

Our policy is to implement controls to prevent foreseeable releases or catastrophic incidents involving regulated substances and adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. Our location Health, Safety, Security, and Environmental (HSSE) Commitment and Policy Statement mirrors our corporate guidelines to address such matters and is signed by the Site General Manager and President of the local union. As part of this commitment, the location has established an HSSE management system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility that includes the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. One component of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that provides a basis for managing risks at the site. The RMP complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) regulation 40 CFR part 68 and the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119.



(b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled;

The location is in Deer Park, Texas along the Houston Ship Channel some 20 miles east of downtown Houston. The Deer Park Refinery ("The Refinery") operates a variety of processes to produce such products as gasoline, jet fuel, kerosene, diesel fuel, heating oil, propane, butane, asphalt, petroleum coke, and chemical feedstocks. 



The regulated fla

mmable substances handled at the facility and the total usage quantities at the site are listed as the following. Usage quantities at each process are listed under Section 1 of the RMP.



Hydrogen, 27,389 lb

Methane, 25,679 lb

Ethane, 47,206 lb

Ethylene [Ethene], 1,676 lb

Propane, 6,645,141 lb

Propylene [1-Propene], 215,673 lb

Isobutane [Propane, 2-methyl], 17,799,018 lb

Butane, 27,249,444 lb

1-Butene, 2,706,564 lb

2-Butene-cis, 2,170,236 lb

2-Butene-trans [2-Butene, (E)], 2,419,533 lb

1,3-butadiene, 32,944 lb

Isopentane [Butane, 2-methyl-], 7,274,632 lb

Pentane, 7,394,099 lb

Butene, 4,051,062 lb

1-Pentene, 211,484 lb

cis-2-pentene, 39,553 lb

trans-2-pentene, 32,188 lb

2-methyl-1-butene, 50,071 lb



(c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; 



Elements of the accident prevention program are captured below.



 Management System



The location General Manager has assigned the HSSE Manager with the overall responsibility for overseeing the implementation of the elements of the RMP, including prevention activities. Key personnel have been assigned to support the effort for development, implementation, and integration of the RMP as per 40 CFR part 68.15.



 Process Safety Information



The location maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help sustain safe operation of the process by using the information to help train employees, perform process hazard analyses, and design and maintain process equipment. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis information. Specific departments and job roles within the site are assigned responsibility for keeping this process safety information up to date.  



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). This info

rmation is complemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, the location has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g. temperature, level, composition), trained personnel, and have established means for monitoring and controlling the process units according to these and other operating limits.



 Process Hazard Analysis



The location has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to assure the risks have been reduced to as low as reasonably practicable.



The location primarily uses a hazard evaluation technique called hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team is led by an experienced facilitator knowledgeable in the type of analysis performed. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as incident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes it is necessary.



The HAZOP team findings are forwarded to local management for resolution and are tracked until closed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained. To help ensure that the process hazard controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the location periodically updates, repeats, or revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years unti

l the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.



 Operating Procedures



The location maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as: (1) initial unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) emergency operations, (6) normal shutdown, (7) normal startup, and (8) start-up following turnaround. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process, through the annual certification process, and by reviewing them as part of the location document control process.



 Training



To complement the written procedures for process operations, the location has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in refinery operations before being assigned to a specific unit. After successfully completing this training, a new employee is paired with a senior employee to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After employees demonstrate (e.g., tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and task in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all employees periodically receive refresher training in the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All of this training is documented for each employee, including the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.



 Mechanical Integrity



The location has well-established practices and

procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and test, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, (5) applying quality assurance measures, and (6) monitoring completion of required inspection and maintenance duties. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Maintenance and mechanical integrity inspection personnel receive training on: (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.



Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is still suitable for use. In the event that a deficiency is identified, employees (if possible) will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a group of experts will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. The Refinery incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper material and spare parts are used when repairs are made.



 Management of Change



The location has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), proc

edures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training to changes being authorized. They are also trained to identify potential and types of changes in their work environment so that they may be addressed.



 Pre-startup Review



The location conducts pre-startup reviews (PSSRs) of any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared to startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. For complex or extensive modifications, the PSSR team uses checklists to verify all aspects for readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that other prevention program requirements were properly implemented. This includes such items as having adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures in place and confirmation that all affected employees are trained before the process is started.



 Compliance Audits



The location conducts audits on the covered processes at least every three years to assure the prevention programs satisfy the requirements of the PSM/RMP standards, are effectively implemented, and continuously maintained. The teams who perform the audits include personnel who possess relevan

t competencies sufficient to provide an appropriate health check of the location process safety program. Both hourly and salaried personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked and their progress reviewed by management on a periodic basis until completed. Affected employees are informed of the audit results. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



 Incident Investigation



The location has a formal program in place for reporting incidents, conducting incident investigations, generating reports, and tracking action items resulting from incidents until they are completed. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings have personnel assigned to each action item and are electronically tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with employees who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during the next Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).



 Employee Participation



The facility recognizes the value of employee participation and provides for and encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. These opportunities are described in a location procedure. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical infor

mation to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis team or investigation team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the location accident prevention program. In addition, the location has a number of initiatives under way that address process and employee safety. 



 Hot Work Permit (Safe Work Practices)



The location has long-standing safe work practices, including hot work permits that are in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Personnel who are to perform hot work are required to receive a hot work permit from a trained and qualified Deer Park employee. Examples of other safe work practices at the location include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) isolation of energy sources for equipment that is being worked on through the use of lockout/tagout procedure, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) control over spark and/or flame-producing activities through the use of a permit and procedure, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with initial and refresher training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed in a safe manner.



 Contractors



The location uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of intense maintenance or construction activities. It also has a standing contractor work force to support the site during normal activities. Because contactors work at this facility, the location has established a contractor program, in partnership with the Houston Area Safety Council and contractor businesses, to foster safe work at the facility. This program is monitored and driven by the location's Contractor HSSE Management Team, composed of both Deer Park and contractor representatives.



(d) The five-year accident history;

The location has had an excellent record of accident prevention over the past five years as there have been no releases of RMP-covered chemicals from RMP-covered processes meeting the reporting criteria.



(e) The emergency response program;

Although the Deer Park Refinery fosters an environment where prevention is of utmost importance, the facility maintains an emergency response program to protect workers, the public, and the environment in the event of loss of containment of a hazardous material or other adverse consequence. The program consists of a highly trained contingent of emergency responders, fixed and mobile equipment, and arrangements with community and private organizations to either support or coordinate response and recovery.



The location emergency response program is coordinated with three area Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPCs). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. The facility has 24 hour a day communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials, municipal emergency response organizations, and industrial mutual aid emergency response organizations. The facility conducts periodic emergency drills in cooperation of the area LEPC, local municipal fire departments, and the Channel Industries Mutual Aid Organization involvement.



(f) Planned changes to improve safety.

Although the Deer Park Refinery has made significant improvements to the location process safety program, the facility continues to make enhancements to improve safety of the facility. To achieve our objective of no harm, management has allocated resources, funding and provided tools for personnel to improve the location safety program. Efforts to drive such improvements are monitored by location senior leadership.
